articles.description:
Posted by Charlie Reis‚Äã and Alex Moshchuk, Chrome Security Team
Chrome's Site Isolation is an essential security defense that makes it harder for malicious web sites to steal data from other web sites. On Windows, Mac, Linux, and Chrome OS, Site Isolation protects all web sites from each other, and also ensures they do not share processes with extensions, which are more highly privileged than web sites. As of Chrome 92, we will start extending this capability so that extensions can no longer share processes‚Ä¶
articles.title: Protecting more with Site Isolation
Advancing an inclusive, diverse security industry

articles.description:
Posted by Ryan Hurst, Production Security Team

The way we design and build software is continually evolving. Just as we now think of security as something we build into software from the start, we are also increasingly looking for new ways to minimize trust in that software. One of the ways we can do that is by designing software so that you can get cryptographic certainty of what the software has done.
In this post, we'll introduce the concept of verifiable data structures that help us get this cryptograp‚Ä¶
articles.title: Verifiable design in modern systems

articles.description:
Posted by Kim Lewandowski, Azeem Shaikh, Laurent Simon, Google Open Source Security Team


Contributors to the Scorecards project, an automated security tool that produces a ‚Äúrisk score‚Äù for open source projects, have accomplished a lot since our launch last fall. Today, in collaboration  with the Open Source Security Foundation community, we are announcing Scorecards v2. We have added new security checks, scaled up the number of projects being scored, and made this data easily accessible for analysis.

Wit‚Ä¶
articles.title: Measuring Security Risks in Open Source Software: Scorecards Launches V2

articles.description:
Posted by Oliver Chang, Google Open Source Security team and Russ Cox, Go team 
In recent months, Google has launched several efforts to strengthen open-source security on multiple fronts. One important focus is improving how we identify and respond to known security vulnerabilities without doing extensive manual work. It is essential to have a precise common data format to triage and remediate security vulnerabilities, particularly when communicating about risks to affected dependencies‚Äîit enables eas‚Ä¶
articles.title: Announcing a unified vulnerability schema for open source

articles.description:
This keeps getting better! We talked with @lawik about the same topic a few weeks back on Ship It! #7. We even did a follow-up YouTube stream. I intend to continue this conversation if Maik is up for it üéô
Discuss on Changelog News
articles.title: No, we don‚Äôt use Kubernetes

articles.description:
Too often, web tiers are full of boilerplate that does nothing except convert a result set into JSON. A middle tier could be as simple as a function call that returns JSON. All we need is an easy way to convert result sets into JSON in the database.
PostgreSQL has built-in JSON generators that can be used to create structured JSON output right in the database, upping performance and radically simplifying web tiers. Fortunately, PostgreSQL has such functions, that run right next to the data, for better perfo‚Ä¶
articles.title: Generating JSON directly from Postgres

articles.description:
On this special edition of The Changelog, we tell Vim‚Äôs story from the mouths of its users. Julia Evans, Drew Neil, Suz Hinton, and Gary Bernhardt join Jerod Santo for a deep and wide-ranging discussion about ‚Äúthe best text editor that anyone ever wrote.‚Äù
Discuss on Changelog News

articles.description:
This expands on topics that we have discussed in Ship It! #11 and covers community findings on the practices that make the biggest difference for:
Higher productivity
Improvement in code quality
End-user satisfaction
Software developer retention

Discuss on Changelog News
articles.title: Mature teams ship better code faster and you can too

articles.description:
In 1984 John Gage of Sun Microsystems was credited as saying ‚ÄúThe Network is the computer.‚Äù Almost four decades ago, John had a vision of distributed systems working together to be greater than the sum of their parts.
For this article, I surveyed the land of hosted IDEs and it turns out that we‚Äôve progressed beyond running VS Code on an iPad whilst sipping a cocktail.
You can still do that, but there‚Äôs way more to it today and I‚Äôll take you through some of use-cases and add my own thoughts. There‚Äôs also a p‚Ä¶
articles.title: The Internet is my computer

articles.description:
Angle-grinder allows you to parse, aggregate, sum, average, min/max, percentile, and sort your data. You can see it, live-updating, in your terminal. Angle grinder is designed for when, for whatever reason, you don‚Äôt have your data in graphite/honeycomb/kibana/sumologic/splunk/etc. but still want to be able to do sophisticated analytics.
Angle grinder can process well above 1M rows per second (simple pipelines as high as 5M), so it‚Äôs usable for fairly meaty aggregation. The results will live update in your ‚Ä¶
articles.title: Slice and dice logs on the command line with Angle Grinder

articles.description:
9 out of 10 AI projects don‚Äôt end up creating value in production. Why? At least partly because these projects utilize unstable models and drifting data. In this episode, Roey from BeyondMinds gives us some insights on how to filter garbage input, detect risky output, and generally develop more robust AI systems.
Discuss on Changelog News
Join Changelog++ to support our work, get closer to the metal, and make the ads disappear!

This week we‚Äôre talking to Rasmus Andersson about his journey as a software creator. We talk about the work he‚Äôs doing right now on Playbit, a computing environment which encourages playful learning, building, and sharing of software. We also talk about his work on the Inter typeface, as well as the reasons why this font family needed to be free and open source.

articles.description:
k6 describes itself as ‚Äúlike unit testing, for performance.‚Äù It‚Äôs an open source tool that can be run locally or on their cloud. The company behind the tool was recently acquired by Grafana, so the project is now a Grafana Labs thing. You write your scripts in JavaScript and they run on a Go backend engine.

articles.description:
There are server colocation providers that allow hosting a 1U server for as low as $30/month, but there‚Äôs a catch: There are restrictions on power usage (1A @ 120v max, for example) because they‚Äôre expecting small and power-efficient network equipment like firewalls.
This repo is about designing a server that fits within the 1U space and 1A @ 120v power constraint while maximizing computing power, storage, and value.

Discuss on Changelog News
articles.title: A low power 1U Raspberry Pi cluster server

articles.description:
The panel discusses all the things that have to happen before you write a lick of code. Then, for Story of the Week: Dan Abramov thinks npm audit is broken by design. We also have thoughts. Lots of ‚Äôem.

articles.description:
I don‚Äôt think I‚Äôve ever had more distrust and as a consequence distate for software than in recent years. I don‚Äôt think its just me as a tech-nerd with artisanal tech-carpentry aspirations. I want people to build well, treat their users right and generally exercise some actual restraint. I see it very clearly and I react more viscerally than anyone non-technical in my surroundings. However, I see the frustrations and the consequences everywhere‚Ä¶
Discuss on Changelog News
articles.title: My trust in software, an all time low

articles.description:
Kishore Nallan:
When I first started working on Typesense six years ago, I set myself a simple rule:
I shall write some code everyday before or after work.
That‚Äôs it. No deadlines, no quarterly goals, no milestones.
Looking back, I cannot believe how much I‚Äôve been able to ship over the past 6 years by just following this one rule.
This rule has served me well in my career as well. Showing up consistently and putting in the work pays dividends over the long-term that you just can‚Äôt see over the short-term. ‚Ä¶
articles.title: The unreasonable effectiveness of just showing up everyday

articles.description:
Doing ops properly is hard. Most of us are failing & learning every day. Some of us manage to have fun too.

Discuss on Changelog News
articles.title: That Sinking Feeling (The #HugOps Song)

articles.description:
Go modules brought about quite a few changes to the Go ecosystem. One of those changes is semantic import versioning (SIV), which has a fairly pronounced effect on how libraries are identified. In this episode we are joined by Tim Heckman and Peter Bourgon to discuss some of the downsides to these changes and how it has lead to what a subset of the Go community refers to as the ‚Äúv2+ problem.‚Äù
Discuss on Changelog News
Join Changelog++ to support our work, get closer to the metal, and make the ads disappear!‚Ä¶
articles.title: Go Time 188: SIV and the V2+ issue

articles.description:
This sounds too good to be true, because it kind of is. There is no escaping the cloud (because of email trust) or the requirement of sysadmin‚Äôing this setup (sending/receiving email is critical). If you slack on the details or upkeep, it‚Äôs your email.
I have been on an ongoing quest to free myself from cloud services for years now. During this time, I have hosted my personal email (@bloomqu.ist) on a Google Apps G Suite Google Workspace account, which, while convenient, also means that my personal emails a‚Ä¶
articles.title: Reliable, deliverable, self-hosted email

articles.description:
This series of interactive lessons and exercises is a great place to start if you want to learn SQL. And trust me: if you don‚Äôt know SQL, you want to learn SQL. Of all the technologies and tools I‚Äôve picked up over the course of my career, SQL has had one of the highest ROIs. It‚Äôs portable across languages/runtimes and has incredible staying power in terms of skill relevancy.
Discuss on Changelog News
articles.title: SQLBolt ‚Äì quickly learn SQL right in your browser

articles.description:
Kaizen means ‚Äúchange for the better‚Äù, continuous improvement in this context. Failure is essential to learning, but how do we learn as a team? The simplest thing is to regularly dedicate time for taking a step back, talking about what works & what doesn‚Äôt, maybe writing some of it down, and eventually deciding what should improve next. I intend to make every 10th Ship It! episode a Kaizen one.
This is the first one when we talk with Adam and Jerod about the things that we want to improve in our setup ov‚Ä¶
articles.title: Ship It! 10: Kaizen! The day half the internet went down

articles.description:
In any software project, over time new features and APIs are added and from time-to-time some of them also become deprecated and eventually get removed. Even huge project such as Kubernetes is no exception to this, yet core parts of its API don‚Äôt really come to mind when thinking about deprecating and eventual removal. So, the question is - could a core object or API in Kubernetes, such as Pod, Deployment or Service be removed and if so, how would that go?
Discuss on Changelog News
articles.title: Could Kubernetes pods ever become deprecated?

articles.description:
Ellen Spertus on Stack Overflow‚Äôs blog:
While there are many resources to help programmers write better code‚Äîsuch as books and static analyzers‚Äîthere are few for writing better comments. While it‚Äôs easy to measure the quantity of comments in a program, it‚Äôs hard to measure the quality, and the two are not necessarily correlated. A bad comment is worse than no comment at all. Here are some rules to help you achieve a happy medium.
I like rule #6 (provide links to the original source of copied code) and rule ‚Ä¶
articles.title: Best practices for writing code comments

articles.description:
HOW HAVE I NOT HEARD OF GIT WORK TREES??? WHAT THE EFF.  They are so incredible.  You have to check them out!!! In this video I go over them briefly, assuming you are smart enough to understand them, and also show you my workflow with vim!  Its fantastic!

articles.title: Twilight is a plugin for Neovim that dims inactive portions of code

articles.description:
This is my third eBook on Go, and it‚Äôs one of the ways I‚Äôm supporting my time to make open source contributions and lead the OpenFaaS community. The book covers samples, examples and techniques that I‚Äôve learned over the past 5-6 years.
The point is not to be an 800-page tomb with tenuous links between content, but code from real open source applications that are run in production at scale.
There‚Äôs been over 300 copies sold already and I‚Äôm offering a money back guarantee if anyone should feel it didn‚Äôt meet‚Ä¶
articles.title: I wrote a book about Everyday Go

articles.description:
This is a follow-up blog post to Ship It! #6 Money flows rule everything
To achieve anything significant you need funding
To get funding you need to persuade the people with the money to part with it
To persuade the people with the money, you need to understand what they value
To understand what they value, you need to understand how their cash flows work
To understand how their cash flow works, you need to understand

your customers/clients and how and why they part with their money
the legal and regulator‚Ä¶
articles.title: If you want to transform IT, start with finance

articles.description:
How did we get from symbolic AI to deep learning models that help your write code (i.e., GitHub and OpenAI‚Äôs new Copilot)? That‚Äôs what Chris and Daniel discuss in this episode about the history and future of deep learning (with some help from an article recently published in ACM and written by the luminaries of deep learning).

Texthero is a python package to work with text data efficiently. It empowers NLP developers with a tool to quickly understand any text-based dataset and it provides a solid pipeline to clean and represent text data, from zero to hero.
Discuss on Changelog News

articles.description:
Emma Catlin writing for Pinterest Engineering:
‚Ä¶ at some point in my first year, I realized something critical: I needed to help the entire team, not just myself, in order to grow to the next engineering level. To start, one of my teammates recommended I review code.
The advice was simple enough ‚Äî use code reviews as a way to learn more about a piece of code and expand my knowledge of our overall system. It turned out code reviews were the perfect way for me to continue my learning journey.
She got better a‚Ä¶
articles.title: How to review code as a junior developer

articles.description: This week on Founders Talk, Adam is joined by Mitch Wainer, previously CMO at DigitalOcean and a member of the founding team. They talk about his journey as an entrepreneur and marketer, the early days at DigitalOcean, and everything that went into disrupting the cloud with blazing fast SSDs. Back in March (2021), DigitalOcean started trading on the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) ‚Äî this obviously earned Mitch and many others a very large payday. They also talk about the work Mitch is doing now with Welcome ‚Ä¶
articles.title: Founders Talk 76: From disrupting the cloud to IPO

articles.description:
Monocle is my universal, personal search engine. It can query across tens of thousands of documents from my blog posts, journal entries, notes, Tweets, contacts, and more to act as my extended memory spanning my entire life. Monocle is designed with a focus on speed, privacy, and hackability. It‚Äôs built to be very specific to the particulars of my personal workflow around data, so probably won‚Äôt work for anyone else.
I‚Äôm logging this for your inspiration, not because you should download it and give it a try‚Ä¶
articles.title: Monocle is a universal, personal search engine

articles.description:
Earthly is language agnostic, ‚Äústeals‚Äù good ideas from Makefiles and Dockerfiles and combines them into one spec, and makes your builds self-contained, repeatable, portable and parallel.
Here‚Äôs a ~5 minute video demoing how to  buil a simple Go app with Earthly

articles.description:
This week we talk with Jean-S√©bastien Pedron, RabbitMQ and FreeBSD contributor, about the importance of good release engineering for core infrastructure. Both Jean-S√©bastien and I have been part of the Core RabbitMQ team for many years now. We have built some of the biggest CI/CD pipelines (check the show notes for one example), wrote and shipped some great code together, while breaking and fixing many things in the process.
We have been wrestling with today‚Äôs topic since 2016. Jean-S√©bastien has some great‚Ä¶
articles.title: Ship It! 9: What is good release engineering?

This week we‚Äôre sharing a recent episode from Founders Talk that we continuously hear about from listeners. Listen and subscribe to Founders Talk at founderstalk.fm and anywhere you listen to podcasts.
On Founders Talk #75 ‚Äî Adam talks with Spencer Kimball, CEO and Co-founder of Cockroach Labs ‚Äî makers of CockroachDB an open source cloud-native distributed SQL database. Cockroach Labs recently raised $160 million dollars on a $2 billion dollar valuation. In this episode, Spencer shares his journey in open s‚Ä¶

They talk about almost instantaneous startup, running interpreted languages at the edge, and take a deep dive into the weeds of how Wasm based modules will change the future of application development.

articles.description:
Difftastic is an experimental structured diff tool that compares files based on their syntax. It is very much unfinished. It works reasonably on very parenthesised data (lisps, JSON), it works sometimes on other languages with sufficient parentheses (Rust, JS), and falls back to a line-oriented diff otherwise.

Discuss on Changelog News

articles.description:
This post does a great job of laying out all of the cumbersome/verbose ways you can solve a problem with regular expressions and then showing the tricky way of doing the same thing without all the hassle. With this trick up your sleeve, you‚Äôll be able to answer all of these questions:
How do I match a word unless it‚Äôs surrounded by quotes?
How do I match xyz except in contexts a, b or c?
How do I match every word except those on a blacklist (or other contexts)?
How do I ignore all content that is bolded (‚Ä¶ ‚Ä¶
articles.title: The best regex trick

articles.description:
Fuzzing is coming to the standard library. We speak to Katie Hockman and Jay Conrod who were part of the team responsible for designing and implementing it. We dig into the details, hear some best practices, where fuzzing can help your code, and learn more about how it works.
Discuss on Changelog News
Join Changelog++ to support our work, get closer to the metal, and make the ads disappear!

Cockroach Labs ‚Äì¬†Scale fast, survive anything, thrive everywhere! CockroachDB is most highly evolved database‚Ä¶

articles.description:
Dan Abramov cuts right to the chase:
Have you heard the story about the boy who cried wolf? Spoiler alert: the wolf eats the sheep. If we don‚Äôt want our sheep to be eaten, we need better tools.
As of today, npm audit is a stain on the entire npm ecosystem. The best time to fix it was before rolling it out as a default. The next best time to fix it is now.
He goes on to lay out how it works, why it‚Äôs broken, and what changes he‚Äôs hoping to see.
Discuss on Changelog News
articles.title: npm audit: broken by design

articles.description:
Tenacity is an easy-to-use, cross-platform multi-track audio editor/recorder for Windows, MacOS, GNU/Linux and other operating systems and is developed by a group of volunteers as open source software.
Sound familiar? Maybe because it‚Äôs a fork of the historically awesome Audacity project that promises:
no telemetry, crash reports and other shenanigans like that!
Not ringing any bells? Check out Audacity‚Äôs privacy policy changes, new CLA, and data collection attempts.
Discuss on Changelog News
articles.title: Tenacity ‚Äì¬†a FLOSS fork of Audacity

articles.description:
Austin Gil explains some of the benefits of using SVG for your site‚Äôs favicon:
Crisp image quality with a single file
Support for emojis
Inline icon (no need for a linked resource)
Dark mode detection (sweet!)
Disclaimer: browser support is not amazing.
Discuss on Changelog News
articles.title: SVG favicons have some cool benefits

articles.description:
In this post, I explain what typeclasses are (an alternative to subtyping polymorphism) and how to use them. I give examples in 4 very different languages to show that this concept is universal. I also show that this idea is very pythonic by comparing our classes implementation with functools.singledispatch.
Check how easy it is to define a typeclass with classes:
from classes import AssociatedType, Supports, typeclass

class Greet(AssociatedType):
    """Special type to represent that some i‚Ä¶
articles.title: Typeclasses in Python

articles.description:
One of our awesome Changelog++ members scratched their own itch:
When you upgrade to Changelog++ you‚Äôre given access to ad-free versions of episodes however they‚Äôre only available in one giant bucket feed instead of through individual show feeds. Though only around 5 new podcast episodes are published weekly, if you‚Äôre coming in as a new listener you‚Äôll have a long backlog list with over one thousand shows. It‚Äôs easier to sift through older episodes when they‚Äôre organized by show, so that‚Äôs what this projec‚Ä¶
articles.title: A GitHub Action to create single-show feeds from your Changelog++ feed

articles.description:
Jacob Kaplan-Moss begins where I often do when discussing estimation:
One study by HBR found that one in six IT projects had cost overruns of over 200% and were late by almost 70%. Another study by McKinsey found that IT projects are on average 45% over budget and 7% over schedule. They found large software projects were particularly bad: software projects with budgets over $15M went over budget by an overage of 66% and had schedule overruns averaging 33%.
Nonetheless, there are good reasons to estimate any‚Ä¶
articles.title: Software estimation is hard. Do it anyway.

articles.description:
Devon Zuegel on startup cities:
While the startup cities industry is still small, it is already quite heterogeneous. Each project has its own distinct set of goals, motivations, and scope. However, this diversity isn‚Äôt fully captured by the vocabulary we use right now.
To help myself create a mental map of the industry, I‚Äôve grouped these motivations into 5 categories. I‚Äôve also included examples of places that personify each motivation.
She goes on to discuss each of the 5 categories: economic opportunity,‚Ä¶
articles.title: What are startup cities for?

articles.description:
This project is a formalized list of checks that can be run against an open source codebase and a Go-based tool to run those checks and provide a report on the project‚Äôs health. Here are a few of the checks it runs, to get an idea of what it‚Äôs all about:
Does the project use fuzzing tools, e.g. OSS-Fuzz?
Does the project cryptographically sign releases?
Does the project contain a security policy?
Discuss on Changelog News
articles.title: Security health metrics for open source projects

articles.description:
Commit groups sounds interesting to me. Anyone reading this familiar with Git innards? Is this doable?
You know the ‚Äúgroup‚Äù facility of vector graphics programs? You draw a couple of shapes, you group them together, and then you can apply transformations to the entire group at once, operating on it as if it were an atomic thing. But when need arises, you can ‚Äúungroup‚Äù it and look deeper.
I‚Äôd love to see that same idea applied to Git commits. In Git, a commit group might just be a named and annotated range o‚Ä¶
articles.title: Things I wish Git had: Commit groups

articles.description:
This week we‚Äôre sharing one of the most popular episodes from our new podcast Ship It. Ship It launched in May and now has 8 episodes in the feed to enjoy‚Ä¶it‚Äôs hosted by Gerhard Lazu, our SRE here at Changelog.
In this episode Gerhard talks with Dave Farley, co-author of Continuous Delivery and the inventor of the Deployment Pipeline. Today, most of us ship code the way we do because 25 years ago, Dave cared enough to drive the change that we now call CI/CD. He is one of the great software engineers: opinio‚Ä¶
articles.title: The Changelog 447: The foundations of Continuous Delivery

articles.description:
Cakebrew is a Mac App (GUI) that lets you do most of the useful tasks you need in Homebrew. Including updating and finding problems with brew doctor!
Installs via Homebrew too - brew install --cask cakebrew

articles.title: Cakebrew - macOS app for Homebrew

articles.description:
Nick Reese joins the party to tell us all about Elder.js, his opinionated static site generator and web framework built with SEO in mind. Elder.js was purpose-built with large, content-heavy websites in mind and already serves in many production capacities. We discuss imposter syndrome, the startup/product mindset, Svelte‚Äôs virtues, and much more.
Discuss on Changelog News
Join Changelog++ to support our work, get closer to the metal, and make the ads disappear!
Sponsors
Retool ‚Äì¬†Retool is a low-code platfo‚Ä¶
articles.title: JS Party 182: The Elder.js Guide to the Galaxy

articles.description:
Every line of code written comes at a price: maintenance. To avoid paying for a lot of code, we build reusable software. The problem with code re-use is that it gets in the way of changing your mind later on.
Deleting code is fun! Let‚Äôs all write code that‚Äôs easy to delete. But how?
To write code that‚Äôs easy to delete: repeat yourself to avoid creating dependencies, but don‚Äôt repeat yourself to manage them. Layer your code too: build simple-to-use APIs out of simpler-to-implement but clumsy-to-use parts. Sp‚Ä¶
articles.title: Write code that is easy to delete, not easy to extend

articles.description:
Solid‚Ä¶ does not use a Virtual DOM. Instead it opts to compile its templates down to real DOM nodes and wrap updates in fine grained reactions. This way when your state updates only the code that depends on it runs.
Solid takes a lot of cues from React, but sets itself apart in that it doesn‚Äôt use a Virtual DOM. Here‚Äôs what Michel Weststrate had to say about it on Twitter:
Not a revolution, but really solid (pun) evolution; clean component model, really efficient run-time model, deeply embedded reactivity. D‚Ä¶
articles.title: Solid ‚Äì¬†a declarative JavaScript library for creating user interfaces

articles.description:
This repository is a collection of various materials and tools that I use every day in my work. It contains a lot of useful information gathered in one piece. It is an invaluable source of knowledge for me that I often look back on.
This repo is meant to only contain the good stuff, but holy cow there‚Äôs a LOT of stuff in here.

articles.title: The Book of Secret Knowledge üìò

articles.description:
Responsive design is evolving. Una Kravets:
Today, when using the term: ‚Äúresponsive design‚Äù, you are most likely thinking about using media queries to change layout when resizing a design from mobile size, to tablet size, through to desktop size.
But soon, this perception of responsive design may be considered as outdated as using tables for page layout.
‚ÄúResponsive‚Äù used to mean a web design would respond based on the size of the device accessing it. In the not-so-distant future, it will mean a web design ‚Ä¶
articles.title: Web design in a component-driven world

articles.description:
Take a tour of Python‚Äôs functools module and learn how to use its higher-order functions to implement caching, overloading, creating decorators and in general how to make your code a bit more functional.

articles.title: The power of higher-order functions in Python

articles.description: Why Cloud Native? What are the guiding principles that you should keep in mind as you are choosing a project from the Cloud Native Landscape? How do you build & ship an app in a Cloud Native way? Katie Gamanji, Ecosystem Advocate @ CNCF and former cloud engineer for American Express, Cond√© Nast and Microsoft, joins Gerhard to cover these topics in the context of the Cloud Native Fundamentals course that she developed. 15,000 students have already enrolled, and the initial feedback has been great. Tune i‚Ä¶
articles.title: Ship It! 8: Cloud Native fundamentals

GAN Theft Auto is a Generative Adversarial Network that recreates the Grand Theft Auto 5 environment. It is created using a GameGAN fork based on NVIDIA‚Äôs GameGAN research.
Source code here.

articles.description:
Sad but true: Git is simply too hard. One thing driving said truth is that undoing things often requires jumping through obscure hoops. Here‚Äôs what Waleed Khan has to say on the matter:
Well, it‚Äôs not that it‚Äôs too easy to lose your data ‚Äî but rather, that it‚Äôs too difficult to recover it. For each operation you want to recover from, there‚Äôs a different ‚Äúmagic‚Äù incantation to undo it. All the data is still there in principle, but it‚Äôs not accessible to many in practice.
Here‚Äôs my theory: novice and intermed‚Ä¶
articles.title: Git undo: we can do better

articles.description:
Dr. Axel Rauschmayer gives us a feel for one of the most exciting new APIs in JavaScript-land.
The Temporal date time API is accessible via the global variable Temporal. It is a pleasure to use:
All objects are immutable. Changing them produces new values, similarly to how strings work in JS.
There is support for time zones and non-Gregorian calendars.
There are several specialized classes for Temporal values (date time values with time zones, date time values without time zones, date values without time zo‚Ä¶
articles.title: Temporal: getting started with JavaScript‚Äôs new date time API

articles.description:
A perspective on incidents that makes a lot of sense actually, and captures the ‚ÄúWhy?‚Äù perfectly. My highlights: Incidents involve more people than we think. Tooling just makes it really hard for them to help. We have more incidents than we realise. We just don‚Äôt hear about them. Your whole team, on the same team. Practice makes perfect.
Discuss on Changelog News
articles.title: Incidents are for everyone

articles.description:
Brave Search has some similarities to DDG (which has been my default for a couple years now), but it‚Äôs different in that it builds its own index vs relying on Bing and Yandex. Brave‚Äôs principles:
Privacy: no tracking or profiling of users.
User-first: the user comes first, not the advertising and data industries.
Independence: Brave has its own search index for answering common queries privately without reliance on other providers.
Choice: soon, options for ad-free paid search and ad-supported search.
Trans‚Ä¶
articles.title: Brave adds a privacy-focused search engine (beta)

articles.description:
Contributing to open-source projects can be intimidating ‚Äì and PostgreSQL is no exception. As a long-time PostgreSQL contributor, Aleks shares his hard-earned tips to help you make your first contribution, or start contributing more.

articles.title: How (and why) to become a PostgreSQL contributor

Sometimes you start a thing and lose interest. Or maybe it brings in some cash, but not what you‚Äôd hoped. Rather than let it languish and eventually die, sell your thing on Tiny Acquisitions.
Sometimes you want to start a thing, but don‚Äôt have a good idea. Or maybe you‚Äôve tried a few times, but nothing that generated income. Rather than start from scratch with an unproven idea, buy a thing on Tiny Acquisitions.

articles.description:
Andrej Karpathy, Sr. Director of AI at Tesla:
We are going to create, digitally sign, and broadcast a Bitcoin transaction in pure Python, from scratch, and with zero dependencies. In the process we‚Äôre going to learn quite a bit about how Bitcoin represents value. Let‚Äôs get it.
This post is a technical deep-dive. At the end he posted a reader exercise which was to steal some bitcoins his wallet. The challenge, of course, was completed within 45 minutes of publishing. üòÅ
Discuss on Changelog News
articles.title: A from-scratch tour of bitcoin in Python

articles.description:
Kathy Korevec has been putting a lot of thought into documentation as part of her work at GitHub:
Wouldn‚Äôt it be great if the docs knew that you were writing a Python app on a Windows machine and that you preferred watching videos instead of reading through text? I want you to find the answer to your questions in the docs, easily and efficiently. When you‚Äôre stuck on a problem and you turn to the docs, there‚Äôs a moment of magic as you find the solution, try it out and it works. In that moment you become unb‚Ä¶
articles.title: Maybe it‚Äôs time we re-think docs

articles.description:
Karsten Silz for InfoQ:
Eight years in the making with 28,000 commits, 7400 pull requests, and 4100 closed issues, Scala 3.0 has been released, delivering a ‚Äúcomplete overhaul of the Scala language‚Äù with new features, updates to the syntax and type systems, and new tools for meta-programming.
Holy wow that must‚Äôve been quite the undertaking. Our Scala coverage is embarrassingly scant. Maybe it‚Äôs time for an episode of The Changelog on the subject? Who would be the ideal guest(s) for such a conversation?
Dis‚Ä¶
articles.title: Scala 3 overhauls language for better developer experience

articles.description:
Chip Huyen has been on both sides of  ML-related interviews and has a lot of expertise on the process:
If you‚Äôve picked up this book because you‚Äôre interested in working with one of the key emerging technologies of the 2020s but not sure where to start, you‚Äôre in the right place. Whether you want to become an ML engineer, a platform engineer, a research scientist, or you want to do ML but don‚Äôt yet know the differences among those titles, I hope that this book will give you some useful pointers.

articles.description:
This week on Ship It! Gerhard talks with Lars Wikman (independent Elixir/BEAM software consultant) why sometimes a monolith running on a single host with continuous backups and a built-in self-restore capability is everything that a small team of developers needs. That‚Äôs right, no Kubernetes or microservices. After 2 years of running changelog.com, a Phoenix monolith, on Kubernetes, what do I think? Join our discuss and find out!
Discuss on Changelog News
Join Changelog++ to support our work, get closer to ‚Ä¶

articles.description:
Benny Powers is NOT pleased with what he believes is missing from the latest React release:
For five years now, there‚Äôs been a concerted, multilateral push to bring React into line with every other major framework on custom elements, enshrined in the HTML and DOM specs for years now. Much effort was spent both in public and behind the scenes to encourage the React core team to implement real support for the standards.
But then the PRs were closed, or ignored without public comment. And the issues languished‚Ä¶
articles.title: What's NOT new in React 18

In this article, I‚Äôd like to explore a couple of implementations of sorting algorithms. However, I‚Äôd like to do so driven by unit tests. The examples are written in Go, but don‚Äôt worry if you never worked with Go before. The emphasis here is on the journey and the joy of building solutions guided by tests!

articles.title: Let's test-drive some sorting algorithms

articles.description: As people searched for the latest information on COVID-19 last year, including school reopenings and travel restrictions, the BBC recognized they needed to find new ways of bringing their journalism to their audiences. They released a new online tool, the BBC Corona Bot, which uses artificial intelligence to draw on BBC News‚Äô explanatory journalism. It responds with an answer to a reader‚Äôs specific question where possible, or points to health authorities‚Äô websites when appropriate. AI technology allowed BBC‚Ä¶
articles.title: Launching the AI Academy for small newsrooms

articles.description:
When I was growing up in Brisbane, Aussie Rules football wasn‚Äôt offered as a school sport ‚Äì and there weren‚Äôt any professional female role models to look up to and learn from. Despite these limitations, we got resourceful. We organized football games in our lunch breaks with friends, using soccer or rugby goal posts and adding sticks or cones to serve as point posts. We practised accuracy using rubbish bins as targets.
A decade later, women have truly made their mark in the AFL. There are, however,¬† many ba‚Ä¶
articles.title: Kick like a pro with Footy Skills Lab

articles.description:
Back in the day, there was a surefire way to tell humans and computers apart: You‚Äôd present a picture of a four-legged friend and ask if it was a cat or dog. A computer couldn‚Äôt identify felines from canines, but we humans could answer with doggone confidence.¬†
That all changed about a decade ago thanks to leaps in computer vision and machine learning ‚Äì specifically,¬† major advancements in neural networks, which can train computers to learn in a way similar to humans. Today, if you give a computer enough im‚Ä¶
articles.title: Ask a Techspert: What‚Äôs a neural network?

articles.description: Over the past year, responsibly developed AI has transformed health screenings, supportedfact-checking to battle misinformation and save lives, predicted Covid-19 cases to support public health, and protected wildlife after bushfires. Developing AI in a way that gets it right for everyone requires openness, transparency, and a clear focus on understanding the societal implications. That is why we were among the first companies to develop and publish AI Principles¬†and why, each year, we share updates on our ‚Ä¶
articles.title: An update on our progress in responsible AI innovation

articles.description: Have you ever noticed that the word art is embedded in the phrase artificial intelligence? Neither did we, but when the opportunity presented itself to explore how artificial intelligence (AI) inspires artistic expression ‚Äî with the help of internationally renowned Canadian artist Douglas Coupland ‚Äî the Google Research team jumped on it. This collaboration, with the support of Google Arts & Culture, culminated in a project called Slogans for the Class of 2030, which spotlights the experiences of the fir‚Ä¶
articles.title: Douglas Coupland fuses AI and art to inspire students

articles.description:
Over recent years, we have seen remarkable progress in AI‚Äôs ability to confront new problems and help solve old ones. Advancing these efforts was one reason we set up the Google Research India lab in 2019, with a particular emphasis on AI research that could make a positive social impact. It‚Äôs also why we've supported nonprofit organizations through the Google AI Impact Challenge.

Working in partnership with Google.org and Google‚Äôs University Relations program, our goal is to help academics and nonprofits ‚Ä¶
articles.title: How we‚Äôre supporting 30 new AI for Social Good projects

articles.description: Today, HackerOne is launching the industry‚Äôs first hacker API. This release is now out of beta and is available to the hacker community. It includes a collection of API endpoints that help automate common workflow tasks. In the past, hackers had to use the UI to complete repetitive tasks on the platform, with no supported mechanism to script or automate their workflows. With the new API, hackers can increase productivity and allocate more time towards creative bug hunting.

The list of potential damage is long, and perpetrators are hiding in the dark web in jurisdictions outside of our control. The question is not whether you will be breached, but when or if it already happened without your knowledge. When a company‚Äôs digital assets are compromised, what would have c‚Ä¶

Also this release we see a few nice JavaScript additions, including private fields and methods for classes, and the at() method for Array, String and TypedArray global objects.
